A Generalized Serre’s Condition

Brent Holmes Department of Mathematics
University of Kansas
Lawrence, KS 66045-7523 USA brentholmes@ku.edu
Abstract.

Throughout, let R𝑅R be a commutative Noetherian ring. A ring R𝑅R satisfies Serre’s condition (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) if for all 𝔭∈Spec⁡R,𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R, 0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{ℓ,dimR𝔭}0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}\}. Serre’s condition has been a topic of expanding interest. In this paper, we examine a generalization of Serre’s condition (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). We say a ring satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) when 0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{ℓ,dimR𝔭−j}0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\} for all 𝔭∈Spec⁡R𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R. We prove generalizations of results for rings satisfying Serre’s condition.

Key words and phrases:
Serre condition, cohomological dimension, Hochster-Huneke graph, Alexander Dual, Reisner’s Criterion, Simplicial Complex, Stanley-Reisner ring, Polarization.
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification: 05E40, 05E45,13C15 ,13D02,13D03,13D45

1. Introduction

Let R𝑅R be a commutative Noetherian ring. Recall Serre’s condition (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}).

Definition 1.1.

A ring R𝑅R satisfies Serre’s condition (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) if for all 𝔭∈Spec⁡R,𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R,

0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{ℓ,dimR𝔭}.0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}\}.

For a d𝑑d-dimensional ring, being Cohen-Macaulay is equivalent to satisfying (Sd)subscript𝑆𝑑(S_{d}). A multitude of authors have examined Serre’s condition, and the popularity of the topic has continued to grow (cf. [DHV16, HTYZN11, MT09, PSFTY14, Ter07, Yan00]). Serre’s condition, like the Cohen-Macaulay condition, ties homological properties to geometric properties. We define a generalization of Serre’s condition, which also links homological properties to geometric properties.

Definition 1.2.

A ring R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) property if for all 𝔭∈Spec⁡R,𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R,

0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{ℓ,dimR𝔭−j}.0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\}.

In this paper, we examine results about (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) from a variety of sources in the literature. We prove generalizations for the (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) property. The following will be used implicitly in the paper when appropriate.

Proposition 1.3.

Let ϕ:R→S:italic-ϕ→𝑅𝑆\phi:R\rightarrow S be a faithfully flat homomorphism of Noetherian rings. Then if S𝑆S satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) then so does R𝑅R.

Proof.

Let 𝔭∈Spec⁡R𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R. Since ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is faithfully flat, there exists 𝔮∈Spec⁡S𝔮Spec𝑆\mathfrak{q}\in\operatorname{Spec}S such that 𝔭=𝔮∩R𝔭𝔮𝑅\mathfrak{p}=\mathfrak{q}\cap R. From [BH98], dimR𝔭=dimS𝔮dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔮\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}=\dim S_{\mathfrak{q}} and 0​p​t​R𝔭=0​p​t​S𝔮0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑆𝔮0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}=0ptS_{\mathfrak{q}}. Thus 0​p​t​R𝔭=0​p​t​S𝔮≥min⁡{n,dimS𝔮−j}=min⁡{n,dimR𝔭−j}0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑆𝔮𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔮𝑗𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}=0ptS_{\mathfrak{q}}\geq\min\{n,\dim S_{\mathfrak{q}}-j\}=\min\{n,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\}. Thus R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). ∎

Remark 1.4.

We shall also make use of the fact that for a Stanley-Reisner ring R𝑅R and its associated simplicial complex ΔΔ\Delta, localizing R𝑅R at a prime 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} generated by variables yields the same ring as the following process. Localize ΔΔ\Delta at a face F𝐹F generated by the variables which are not generators of 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p}. Then localize the Stanley-Reisner ring of lkΔ⁡FsubscriptlkΔ𝐹\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}F at it’s unique maximal homogeneous ideal. Throughout the paper, we shall use R𝔭subscript𝑅𝔭R_{\mathfrak{p}} and the Stanley-Reisner ring of lkΔ⁡FsubscriptlkΔ𝐹\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}F interchangeably for convenience and brevity.

We now describe the organization of the paper.

In Section 222, we prove an equivalence between rings satisfying (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) and the support of ExtExt\operatorname{Ext} functors. In this section we consider rings of the form R=S/I𝑅𝑆𝐼R=S/I where S𝑆S is an n𝑛n-dimensional polynomial ring and I𝐼I is a homogeneous ideal or S𝑆S is an n𝑛n-dimensional complete regular local ring and I𝐼I is an ideal of S𝑆S.

In Section 333, we examine theorems from the literature which bound cohomological dimension when R𝑅R satisfies (S2)subscript𝑆2(S_{2}) or (S3)subscript𝑆3(S_{3}). We prove generalizations of these bounds that apply when R𝑅R is equidimensional and satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) or (S3j)superscriptsubscript𝑆3𝑗(S_{3}^{j}). Using these bounds, we bound projective dimension of R𝑅R when 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} is a pure square-free monomial ideal and R𝑅R satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) or (S3j)superscriptsubscript𝑆3𝑗(S_{3}^{j}). In this section we will consider S𝑆S to be an n𝑛n-dimensional regular local ring containing a field, 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} to be an ideal of S𝑆S of pure height and our ring to be R=S/𝔞𝑅𝑆𝔞R=S/\mathfrak{a}.

In Section 444, we consider the Hochster-Huneke graph of R𝑅R (denoted by G​(R)𝐺𝑅G(R)) where R𝑅R is a local ring or a quotient of a polynomial ring and a homogeneous ideal. It is known that a Stanley-Reisner ring satisfies (S2)subscript𝑆2(S_{2}) if and only if every localization of R𝑅R at a prime has a connected Hochster-Huneke graph [Kum08, Hol18]. We create a generalization of the Hochster-Huneke graph. We show that every localization of R𝑅R at a prime has a connected generalized Hochster-Huneke graph if and only if R𝑅R satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}).

In Section 555, we expand upon a result of Yanagawa [Yan00] which states that a Stanley-Reisner ring S/I𝑆𝐼S/I satisfies (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) if and only if the Alexander dual of I𝐼I satisfies a specific homological condition. We combine this result with Theorem 3.4 to prove a bound on regularity of pure square-free monomial ideals.

Given a Stanley-Reisner ring R𝑅R with simplicial complex ΔΔ\Delta, Reisner’s criterion provides a method to check the Cohen-Macaulayness of R𝑅R by examining the reduced homology groups of ΔΔ\Delta [Rei76]. Terai made an analogous theorem for describing whether R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) [Ter07]. In Section 666, we generalize Terai’s result by giving an equivalent condition for (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) using homology of links in the equidimensional case.

In section 777, we examine monomial ideals of polynomial rings over a field. Herzog, Takayama, and Terai [HTT05] proved for a monomial ideal I𝐼I and a polynomial ring S𝑆S, S/I𝑆𝐼S/I being Cohen-Macaulay implies S/I𝑆𝐼S/\sqrt{I} is Cohen-Macaulay. We present an analogous theorem showing S/I𝑆𝐼S/I satisfying (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) implies S/I𝑆𝐼S/\sqrt{I} satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}).

In section 888, we prove a theorem relating i𝑖i-skeletons of simplicial complexes and the (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) property. We discuss i𝑖i-skeletons’ importance with respect to depth.

Unless otherwise stated, 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} will be a field, S=𝕂​[x1,x2,…,xn]𝑆𝕂subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛S=\mathbb{K}[x_{1},x_{2},...,x_{n}], and I𝐼I will be an ideal of S𝑆S.

2. An Equivalent Functorial Condition

In this section, we characterize generalized Serre’s condition as a homological condition. This is an extension of a well-known theorem (see for example [DHV16, Proposition 2.6]).

A catenary noetherian local ring satisfying (S2)subscript𝑆2(S_{2}) is equidimensional by [Har62, Remark 2.4.1]. This is not true for (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}), j>0𝑗0j>0, and thus we will need the following notation.

Given a ring R=S/I𝑅𝑆𝐼R=S/I, let QIsubscript𝑄𝐼Q_{I} be a minimal prime of I𝐼I of smallest height. Given a prime 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} which contains I𝐼I, let Q𝔭subscript𝑄𝔭Q_{\mathfrak{p}} be a minimal prime of I𝐼I contained in 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} with smallest height. Let α𝔭=0​p​t​Q𝔭−0​p​t​QIsubscript𝛼𝔭0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑄𝔭0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑄𝐼\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}=0ptQ_{\mathfrak{p}}-0ptQ_{I}. We note that α𝔭=0subscript𝛼𝔭0\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}=0 for all 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} when R𝑅R is equidimensional.

Theorem 2.1.

Let S𝑆S be an n𝑛n-dimensional polynomial ring with maximal homogenous ideal 𝔪𝔪\mathfrak{m} and let I𝐼I be a homogeneous ideal or let S𝑆S be an n𝑛n-dimensional complete regular local ring with maximal ideal 𝔪𝔪\mathfrak{m} and let I𝐼I be an ideal of S𝑆S. Let R=S/I𝑅𝑆𝐼R=S/I and let d=dimR𝑑dimension𝑅d=\dim R. Then R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) if and only if for all 𝔭∈Spec⁡S𝔭Spec𝑆\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}S containing I𝐼I with 0​p​t​𝔭<n−i+ℓ0𝑝𝑡𝔭𝑛𝑖ℓ0pt\mathfrak{p}<n-i+\ell, we have that 𝔭∉Supp⁡ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)𝔭SuppsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆\mathfrak{p}\notin\operatorname{Supp}\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S) for all i=0,…,d−j−1−α𝔭𝑖0…𝑑𝑗1subscript𝛼𝔭i=0,...,d-j-1-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}.

Proof.

Suppose R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). If i<ℓ≤0​p​t​R𝑖ℓ0𝑝𝑡𝑅i<\ell\leq 0ptR then H𝔪i​(R)=0=ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)superscriptsubscript𝐻𝔪𝑖𝑅0superscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆H_{\mathfrak{m}}^{i}(R)=0=\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S) , and we are finished. Otherwise, let us take 𝔭∈Spec⁡S𝔭Spec𝑆\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}S such that I⊆𝔭𝐼𝔭I\subseteq\mathfrak{p}. Let hℎh be the height of 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p}. If h<n−i+ℓℎ𝑛𝑖ℓh<n-i+\ell, then

ExtSn−i(R,S)𝔭≅ExtS𝔭n−i(R𝔭,S𝔭)=0 for all i=0,…,d−j−1−α𝔭.\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S)_{\mathfrak{p}}\cong\operatorname{Ext}_{S_{\mathfrak{p}}}^{n-i}(R_{\mathfrak{p}},S_{\mathfrak{p}})=0\quad\textrm{ for all }i=0,...,d-j-1-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}.

This is true because n−i=h−(h−n+i)𝑛𝑖ℎℎ𝑛𝑖n-i=h-(h-n+i) and dimR𝔭−j=h−n+d−j−α𝔭>h−n+idimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗ℎ𝑛𝑑𝑗subscript𝛼𝔭ℎ𝑛𝑖\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j=h-n+d-j-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}>h-n+i. So 𝔭∉Supp⁡ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)𝔭SuppsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆\mathfrak{p}\notin\operatorname{Supp}\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S) for i=0,…,d−j−1−α𝔭𝑖0…𝑑𝑗1subscript𝛼𝔭i=0,...,d-j-1-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}} whenever 0​p​t​𝔭<n−(i−ℓ)0𝑝𝑡𝔭𝑛𝑖ℓ0pt\mathfrak{p}<n-(i-\ell).

Suppose 𝔭∉Supp⁡ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)𝔭SuppsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆\mathfrak{p}\notin\operatorname{Supp}\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S) for i=0,…,d−j−1−α𝔭𝑖0…𝑑𝑗1subscript𝛼𝔭i=0,...,d-j-1-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}} whenever 0​p​t​𝔭<n−(i−ℓ)0𝑝𝑡𝔭𝑛𝑖ℓ0pt\mathfrak{p}<n-(i-\ell). Let Vhsubscript𝑉ℎV_{h} be the set of prime ideals of S𝑆S of height hℎh containing I𝐼I for h=n−d,…,nℎ𝑛𝑑…𝑛h=n-d,...,n. Henceforth, let us use c𝑐c to denote n−d𝑛𝑑n-d.

Then we have the following equivalences:

R​ satisfies ​(Sℓj)⇔𝑅 satisfies superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗⇔R\textrm{ satisfies }(S_{\ell}^{j})\quad\Leftrightarrow
0ptR𝔭≥min{ℓ,h−c−j−α𝔭}=:b for all h=c,…,n for all 𝔭∈Vh⇔0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,h-c-j-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}\}=:b\quad\textrm{ for all }h=c,...,n\textrm{ for all }\mathfrak{p}\in V_{h}\quad\Leftrightarrow
H𝔭​S𝔭i​(R𝔭)=0 for all ​h=c,…,n​ for all ​𝔭∈Vh, for all ​i<b⇔formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝔭subscript𝑆𝔭𝑖subscript𝑅𝔭0formulae-sequence for all ℎ𝑐…formulae-sequence𝑛 for all 𝔭subscript𝑉ℎ for all 𝑖𝑏⇔H_{\mathfrak{p}S_{\mathfrak{p}}}^{i}(R_{\mathfrak{p}})=0\quad\textrm{ for all }h=c,...,n\textrm{ for all }\mathfrak{p}\in V_{h},\textrm{ for all }i<b\quad\Leftrightarrow
ExtS𝔭h−i⁡(R𝔭,S𝔭)=0​ for all ​h=c,…,n​ for all ​𝔭∈Vh, for all ​i<b⇔formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptExtsubscript𝑆𝔭ℎ𝑖subscript𝑅𝔭subscript𝑆𝔭0 for all ℎ𝑐…𝑛 for all 𝔭subscript𝑉ℎ for all 𝑖𝑏⇔\operatorname{Ext}_{S_{\mathfrak{p}}}^{h-i}(R_{\mathfrak{p}},S_{\mathfrak{p}})=0\textrm{ for all }h=c,...,n\textrm{ for all }\mathfrak{p}\in V_{h},\textrm{ for all }i<b\quad\Leftrightarrow
𝔭∉Supp⁡ExtSh−i⁡(R,S)​ for all ​h=c,…,n​ for all ​𝔭∈Vh, for all ​i<b.formulae-sequence𝔭SuppsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆ℎ𝑖𝑅𝑆 for all ℎ𝑐…𝑛 for all 𝔭subscript𝑉ℎ for all 𝑖𝑏\mathfrak{p}\notin\operatorname{Supp}\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{h-i}(R,S)\textrm{ for all }h=c,...,n\textrm{ for all }\mathfrak{p}\in V_{h},\textrm{ for all }i<b.

When i<b≤h−c−j−α𝔭𝑖𝑏ℎ𝑐𝑗subscript𝛼𝔭i<b\leq h-c-j-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}, n−h+i<n−c−j−α𝔭=d−j−α𝔭𝑛ℎ𝑖𝑛𝑐𝑗subscript𝛼𝔭𝑑𝑗subscript𝛼𝔭n-h+i<n-c-j-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}=d-j-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}.

From the assumption, for all n−h+i<d−j−α𝔭𝑛ℎ𝑖𝑑𝑗subscript𝛼𝔭n-h+i<d-j-\alpha_{\mathfrak{p}}, 𝔭∉Supp⁡ExtSn−(n−h+i)⁡(R,S)𝔭SuppsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑛ℎ𝑖𝑅𝑆\mathfrak{p}\notin\operatorname{Supp}\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-(n-h+i)}(R,S) whenever h≤n−(n−h+i−ℓ)ℎ𝑛𝑛ℎ𝑖ℓh\leq n-(n-h+i-\ell); thus,

𝔭∉Supp⁡ExtSh−i⁡(R,S)=Supp⁡ExtSn−(n−h+i)⁡(R,S)​ for all ​i<b.𝔭SuppsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆ℎ𝑖𝑅𝑆SuppsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑛ℎ𝑖𝑅𝑆 for all 𝑖𝑏\mathfrak{p}\notin\operatorname{Supp}\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{h-i}(R,S)=\operatorname{Supp}\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-(n-h+i)}(R,S)\textrm{ for all }i<b.

∎

The result can be stated in a cleaner way when the ring in question is equidimensional. In the equidimensional case, the above proof can be adjusted to give:

Corollary 2.2.

Let S𝑆S be an n𝑛n-dimensional polynomial ring with maximal homogenous ideal 𝔪𝔪\mathfrak{m} and let I𝐼I be a homogeneous ideal or let S𝑆S be an n𝑛n-dimensional complete regular local ring with maximal ideal 𝔪𝔪\mathfrak{m} and let I𝐼I be an ideal of S𝑆S. Let R=S/I𝑅𝑆𝐼R=S/I be an equidimensional ring. Then R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) if and only if dimExtSn−i⁡(R,S)≤i−ℓdimensionsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆𝑖ℓ\dim\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S)\leq i-\ell for all i=0,…,d−j−1𝑖0…𝑑𝑗1i=0,...,d-j-1.

3. Bounds on Cohomological Dimension

Local cohomology is widely important in the fields of commutative algebra and algebraic geometry. The vanishing of local cohomology is subject to deep analysis throughout the fields. One measure of this vanishing is the cohomological dimension. Let S𝑆S be a Noetherian local ring and 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} be an ideal of S𝑆S. The cohomological dimension of 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} in S𝑆S is:

cd(S,𝔞)=sup{i∈ℤ≥0|H𝔞i(M)≠0\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})=\sup\{i\in\mathds{Z}_{\geq 0}|H_{\mathfrak{a}}^{i}(M)\neq 0 for some S𝑆S-module M}M\}.

The cohomological dimension has been a topic garnering wide interest (cf. [Har68, Ogu73, PS73, HL90, Lyu93, Var13, DT16]). It is known that cd⁡(S,𝔞)cd𝑆𝔞\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a}) is less than or equal to dimSdimension𝑆\dim S. We desire to improve this bound for special cases. We will take advantage of various existing results to aid in this endeavor. If 0​p​t​S/𝔞≥10𝑝𝑡𝑆𝔞10ptS/\mathfrak{a}\geq 1, then cd⁡(S,𝔞)≤n−1cd𝑆𝔞𝑛1\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq n-1, which is an immediate consequence of the Hartshorne-Lichtenbaum vanishing theorem ([Har68, Theorem 3.1]). From the work of Ogus, we have 0​p​t​S/𝔞≥20𝑝𝑡𝑆𝔞20ptS/\mathfrak{a}\geq 2, then cd⁡(S,𝔞)≤n−2cd𝑆𝔞𝑛2\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq n-2 (Remark below Corollary 2.11 [Ogu73]).

In [HL90], Huneke and Lyubeznik prodce a theorem which helps construct more of these bounds. In [DT16], the theorem is reinterpreted for convenience of application.

Theorem 3.1 (Huneke-Lyubeznik, see [DT16, Theorem 3.7]).

Let (S,m) be a d𝑑d-dimensional regular local ring containing a field and let 𝔞⊂S𝔞𝑆\mathfrak{a}\subset S be an ideal of pure height c𝑐c. Let f𝑓f ::: ℕ→ℕ→ℕℕ\mathds{N}\rightarrow\mathds{N} be a non-decreasing function. Assume there exist integers ℓ′≥ℓ≥csuperscriptℓ′ℓ𝑐\ell^{\prime}\geq\ell\geq c such that:

(111) f​(ℓ)≥c𝑓ℓ𝑐f(\ell)\geq c,

(222) cd⁡(S𝔭,𝔞𝔭)≤f​(ℓ′+1)−c+1cdsubscript𝑆𝔭subscript𝔞𝔭𝑓superscriptℓ′1𝑐1\operatorname{cd}(S_{\mathfrak{p}},\mathfrak{a}_{\mathfrak{p}})\leq f(\ell^{\prime}+1)-c+1 for all prime ideals 𝔭⊃𝔞𝔞𝔭\mathfrak{p}\supset\mathfrak{a} with 0​p​t​𝔭≤ℓ−10𝑝𝑡𝔭ℓ10pt\mathfrak{p}\leq\ell-1,

(333) cd⁡(S𝔭,𝔞𝔭)≤f​(0​p​t​𝔭)cdsubscript𝑆𝔭subscript𝔞𝔭𝑓0𝑝𝑡𝔭\operatorname{cd}(S_{\mathfrak{p}},\mathfrak{a}_{\mathfrak{p}})\leq f(0pt\mathfrak{p}) for all prime ideals 𝔭⊃𝔞𝔞𝔭\mathfrak{p}\supset\mathfrak{a} with ℓ≤0​p​t​𝔭≤ℓ′ℓ0𝑝𝑡𝔭superscriptℓ′\ell\leq 0pt\mathfrak{p}\leq\ell^{\prime},

(444) f​(r−s−1)≤f​(r)−s𝑓𝑟𝑠1𝑓𝑟𝑠f(r-s-1)\leq f(r)-s for every r≥ℓ′+1𝑟superscriptℓ′1r\geq\ell^{\prime}+1 and every c−1≥s≥1𝑐1𝑠1c-1\geq s\geq 1.

Then cd⁡(S,𝔞)≤f​(d)cd𝑆𝔞𝑓𝑑\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq f(d) if d≥ℓ𝑑ℓd\geq\ell.

In [DT16], Dao and Takagi proved the following corollary:

Corollary 3.2 (Dao-Takagi).

Let (S,𝔪)𝑆𝔪(S,\mathfrak{m}) be an n𝑛n-dimensional regular local ring essentially of finite type over a field. If 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} is an ideal of S𝑆S such that 0​p​t​S/𝔞≥30𝑝𝑡𝑆𝔞30ptS/\mathfrak{a}\geq 3, then cd⁡(S,𝔞)≤n−3cd𝑆𝔞𝑛3\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq n-3.

Dao and Takagi then used this corollary in conjuction with Theorem 3.13.13.1 to prove:

Theorem 3.3 (Dao-Takagi).

Let S𝑆S be an n𝑛n-dimensional regular local ring containing a field and let 𝔞⊂S𝔞𝑆\mathfrak{a}\subset S be an ideal of height c𝑐c.

(1) If S/𝔞𝑆𝔞S/\mathfrak{a} satisfies Serre’s condition (S2)subscript𝑆2(S_{2}) and dimS/𝔞≥1dimension𝑆𝔞1\dim S/\mathfrak{a}\geq 1, then

cd⁡(S,𝔞)≤n−1−⌊n−2c⌋cd𝑆𝔞𝑛1𝑛2𝑐\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq n-1-\lfloor\frac{n-2}{c}\rfloor

(2) Suppose that S𝑆S is essentially of finite type over a field. If S/𝔞𝑆𝔞S/\mathfrak{a} satisfies Serre’s condition (S3)subscript𝑆3(S_{3}) and dimS/𝔞≥2dimension𝑆𝔞2\dim S/\mathfrak{a}\geq 2, then

cd⁡(S,𝔞)≤n−2−⌊n−3c⌋cd𝑆𝔞𝑛2𝑛3𝑐\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq n-2-\lfloor\frac{n-3}{c}\rfloor

In this paper, we generalize this theorem to consider (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) and (S3j)superscriptsubscript𝑆3𝑗(S_{3}^{j}) for any j𝑗j.

Theorem 3.4.

Let S𝑆S be an n𝑛n-dimensional regular local ring containing a field and let 𝔞⊂S𝔞𝑆\mathfrak{a}\subset S be a pure ideal of height c𝑐c.

(111) If S/𝔞𝑆𝔞S/\mathfrak{a} satisfies Serre’s condition (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) and dimS/𝔞≥1+jdimension𝑆𝔞1𝑗\dim S/\mathfrak{a}\geq 1+j, then

cd⁡(S,𝔞)≤n−1−⌊n−2−jc⌋cd𝑆𝔞𝑛1𝑛2𝑗𝑐\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq n-1-\lfloor\frac{n-2-j}{c}\rfloor

(222) Suppose that S𝑆S is essentially of finite type over a field. If S/𝔞𝑆𝔞S/\mathfrak{a} satisfies Serre’s condition (S3j)superscriptsubscript𝑆3𝑗(S_{3}^{j}) and dimS/𝔞≥2+jdimension𝑆𝔞2𝑗\dim S/\mathfrak{a}\geq 2+j, then

cd⁡(S,𝔞)≤n−2−⌊n−3−jc⌋cd𝑆𝔞𝑛2𝑛3𝑗𝑐\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq n-2-\lfloor\frac{n-3-j}{c}\rfloor

Proof.

For (111) we apply Theorem 3.13.13.1 with f​(m)=m−1−⌊m−2−jc⌋𝑓𝑚𝑚1𝑚2𝑗𝑐f(m)=m-1-\lfloor\frac{m-2-j}{c}\rfloor, ℓ=c+1+jℓ𝑐1𝑗\ell=c+1+j, and ℓ′=2​c+1+jsuperscriptℓ′2𝑐1𝑗\ell^{\prime}=2c+1+j. Condition (2) of Theorem 3.13.13.1 becomes cd⁡(S𝔭,𝔞𝔭)≤c+jcdsubscript𝑆𝔭subscript𝔞𝔭𝑐𝑗\operatorname{cd}(S_{\mathfrak{p}},\mathfrak{a}_{\mathfrak{p}})\leq c+j for all primes of height at most c+j𝑐𝑗c+j. This follows since cd⁡(S𝔭,𝔞𝔭)≤0​p​t​𝔭≤c+jcdsubscript𝑆𝔭subscript𝔞𝔭0𝑝𝑡𝔭𝑐𝑗\operatorname{cd}(S_{\mathfrak{p}},\mathfrak{a}_{\mathfrak{p}})\leq 0pt\mathfrak{p}\leq c+j. Condition (3) of Theorem 3.13.13.1 breaks into two cases. If 0​p​t​𝔭=ℓ0𝑝𝑡𝔭ℓ0pt\mathfrak{p}=\ell then we get cd⁡(S𝔭,𝔞𝔭)≤0​p​t​𝔭−1cdsubscript𝑆𝔭subscript𝔞𝔭0𝑝𝑡𝔭1\operatorname{cd}(S_{\mathfrak{p}},\mathfrak{a}_{\mathfrak{p}})\leq 0pt\mathfrak{p}-1. This is true, since 0​p​t​S𝔭/𝔞​S𝔭≥min⁡{2,c+j+1−c−j}=10𝑝𝑡subscript𝑆𝔭𝔞subscript𝑆𝔭2𝑐𝑗1𝑐𝑗10ptS_{\mathfrak{p}}/\mathfrak{a}S_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{2,c+j+1-c-j\}=1. If 0​p​t​𝔭>ℓ0𝑝𝑡𝔭ℓ0pt\mathfrak{p}>\ell then we get cd⁡(S𝔭,𝔞𝔭)≤0​p​t​𝔭−2cdsubscript𝑆𝔭subscript𝔞𝔭0𝑝𝑡𝔭2\operatorname{cd}(S_{\mathfrak{p}},\mathfrak{a}_{\mathfrak{p}})\leq 0pt\mathfrak{p}-2. This is true, since 0​p​t​S𝔭/𝔞​S𝔭≥20𝑝𝑡subscript𝑆𝔭𝔞subscript𝑆𝔭20ptS_{\mathfrak{p}}/\mathfrak{a}S_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq 2.

For (222) we apply Theorem 3.13.13.1 with f​(m)=m−2−⌊m−3−jc⌋𝑓𝑚𝑚2𝑚3𝑗𝑐f(m)=m-2-\lfloor\frac{m-3-j}{c}\rfloor, ℓ=c+2+jℓ𝑐2𝑗\ell=c+2+j, and ℓ′=2​c+2+jsuperscriptℓ′2𝑐2𝑗\ell^{\prime}=2c+2+j. Condition (2) of Theorem 3.13.13.1 breaks into two cases. If 0​p​t​𝔭=ℓ−10𝑝𝑡𝔭ℓ10pt\mathfrak{p}=\ell-1, then cd⁡(S𝔭,𝔞𝔭)≤0​p​t​𝔭−1cdsubscript𝑆𝔭subscript𝔞𝔭0𝑝𝑡𝔭1\operatorname{cd}(S_{\mathfrak{p}},\mathfrak{a}_{\mathfrak{p}})\leq 0pt\mathfrak{p}-1. This is true since 0​p​t​S𝔭/𝔞​S𝔭≥10𝑝𝑡subscript𝑆𝔭𝔞subscript𝑆𝔭10ptS_{\mathfrak{p}}/\mathfrak{a}S_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq 1. Otherwise, (2) becomes cd⁡(S𝔭,𝔞𝔭)≤0​p​t​𝔭cdsubscript𝑆𝔭subscript𝔞𝔭0𝑝𝑡𝔭\operatorname{cd}(S_{\mathfrak{p}},\mathfrak{a}_{\mathfrak{p}})\leq 0pt\mathfrak{p}, which is true. Demonstrating condition (333) of Theorem 3.13.13.1 has two parts. If 0​p​t​𝔭=ℓ=c+2+j0𝑝𝑡𝔭ℓ𝑐2𝑗0pt\mathfrak{p}=\ell=c+2+j, then 0​p​t​S/𝔞≥20𝑝𝑡𝑆𝔞20ptS/\mathfrak{a}\geq 2, and thus we have c​d​(S,𝔞)≤0​p​t​𝔭−2=f​(0​p​t​𝔭)𝑐𝑑𝑆𝔞0𝑝𝑡𝔭2𝑓0𝑝𝑡𝔭cd(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq 0pt\mathfrak{p}-2=f(0pt\mathfrak{p}). If c+3+j≤0​p​t​𝔭≤2​c+2+j𝑐3𝑗0𝑝𝑡𝔭2𝑐2𝑗c+3+j\leq 0pt\mathfrak{p}\leq 2c+2+j, then f​(0​p​t​𝔭)=0​p​t​𝔭−3𝑓0𝑝𝑡𝔭0𝑝𝑡𝔭3f(0pt\mathfrak{p})=0pt\mathfrak{p}-3. However, 0​p​t​S𝔭/𝔞​S𝔭≥30𝑝𝑡subscript𝑆𝔭𝔞subscript𝑆𝔭30ptS_{\mathfrak{p}}/\mathfrak{a}S_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq 3. Therefore, Corollary 3.23.23.2 implies cd⁡(S𝔭,𝔞𝔭)≤0​p​t​𝔭−3cdsubscript𝑆𝔭subscript𝔞𝔭0𝑝𝑡𝔭3\operatorname{cd}(S_{\mathfrak{p}},\mathfrak{a}_{\mathfrak{p}})\leq 0pt\mathfrak{p}-3. ∎

Corollary 3.5.

Let S𝑆S be an n𝑛n-dimensional regular local ring containing a field and let 𝔞⊂S𝔞𝑆\mathfrak{a}\subset S be a pure, square-free monomial ideal of height c𝑐c.

(111) If S/𝔞𝑆𝔞S/\mathfrak{a} satisfies Serre’s condition (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) and dimS/𝔞≥1+jdimension𝑆𝔞1𝑗\dim S/\mathfrak{a}\geq 1+j, then

pd⁡S/𝔞≤n−1−⌊n−2−jc⌋pd𝑆𝔞𝑛1𝑛2𝑗𝑐\operatorname{pd}S/\mathfrak{a}\leq n-1-\lfloor\frac{n-2-j}{c}\rfloor

(222) Suppose that S𝑆S is essentially of finite type over a field. If S/𝔞𝑆𝔞S/\mathfrak{a} satisfies Serre’s condition (S3j)superscriptsubscript𝑆3𝑗(S_{3}^{j}) and dimS/𝔞≥2+jdimension𝑆𝔞2𝑗\dim S/\mathfrak{a}\geq 2+j, then

pd⁡S/𝔞≤n−2−⌊n−3−jc⌋pd𝑆𝔞𝑛2𝑛3𝑗𝑐\operatorname{pd}S/\mathfrak{a}\leq n-2-\lfloor\frac{n-3-j}{c}\rfloor

Proof.

When 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} is a square-free monomial ideal, cd⁡(S,𝔞)=pd⁡S/𝔞cd𝑆𝔞pd𝑆𝔞\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})=\operatorname{pd}S/\mathfrak{a} [Lyu]. Therefore, applying Theorem 3.43.43.4 we get the desired bounds. ∎

4. A generalized Hochster-Huneke graph

For this section we consider two kinds of rings, local rings and rings which are a quotient of a polynomial ring and a homogeneous ideal. When we say ring, we shall mean these types of rings unless otherwise noted.

The Hochster-Huneke graph is a graphical representation of the minimal prime ideals of a ring R. This graph is sometimes called the dual graph of Spec⁡RSpec𝑅\operatorname{Spec}R and has been examined from many perspectives throughout the literature (cf [HH94, BBV17, BV15, Hol18]). The connectivity of the Hochster-Huneke graph and its localizations provides information about algebraic properties of R𝑅R. We will consider a generalization of the Hochster-Huneke graph.

Definition 4.1 ([HH94]).

Let G​(R)𝐺𝑅G(R) be the graph with V​(G​(R))={vi=Pi}𝑉𝐺𝑅subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖V(G(R))=\{v_{i}=P_{i}\} where the Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} are the minimal primes of R𝑅R, E​(G​(R))={(vk,vℓ)|0​p​t​(𝔭k+𝔭ℓ)=1}𝐸𝐺𝑅conditional-setsubscript𝑣𝑘subscript𝑣ℓ0𝑝𝑡subscript𝔭𝑘subscript𝔭ℓ1E(G(R))=\{(v_{k},v_{\ell})|0pt(\mathfrak{p}_{k}+\mathfrak{p}_{\ell})=1\}. Then G​(R)𝐺𝑅G(R) is the Hochster-Huneke graph of R𝑅R.

Definition 4.2.

A ring is locally connected if for any 𝔭∈Spec⁡R𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R, G​(R𝔭)𝐺subscript𝑅𝔭G(R_{\mathfrak{p}}) is connected.

Theorem 4.3 ([Kum08, Theorem 6.1.5], [Hol18, Theorem 2.15]).

Let R𝑅R be a Stanley-Reisner ring. Then R𝑅R satisfies (S2)subscript𝑆2(S_{2}) if and only if R𝑅R is locally connected.

We desire to make a generalized Hochster-Huneke graph in order to make an analogue of the previous theorem for rings satisfying (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}). We note that our generalization is the same generalization given in [NBSW17].

Definition 4.4.

Let Gj​(R)superscript𝐺𝑗𝑅G^{j}(R) be the graph with V​(Gj​(R))={vi=Pi}𝑉superscript𝐺𝑗𝑅subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖V(G^{j}(R))=\{v_{i}=P_{i}\} where the 𝔭isubscript𝔭𝑖\mathfrak{p}_{i} are the minimal primes of R𝑅R, E​(Gj​(R))={(vk,vℓ)|1≤0​p​t​(𝔭k+𝔭ℓ)≤j}𝐸superscript𝐺𝑗𝑅conditional-setsubscript𝑣𝑘subscript𝑣ℓ10𝑝𝑡subscript𝔭𝑘subscript𝔭ℓ𝑗E(G^{j}(R))=\{(v_{k},v_{\ell})|1\leq 0pt(\mathfrak{p}_{k}+\mathfrak{p}_{\ell})\leq j\}. We note G1​(R)superscript𝐺1𝑅G^{1}(R) is the Hochster-Huneke graph of R𝑅R.

Definition 4.5.

A ring is j𝑗j-locally connected if for any 𝔭∈Spec⁡R𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R, Gj​(R𝔭)superscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝑅𝔭G^{j}(R_{\mathfrak{p}}) is connected.

Theorem 4.6.

Let R𝑅R be a Stanley-Reisner ring. Then, R𝑅R satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) if and only if R𝑅R is j+1𝑗1j+1-locally connected.

Proof.

By Theorem 2.12.12.1, we have R𝑅R satisfying (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) can be viewed as a condition on Supp⁡ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)SuppsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆\operatorname{Supp}\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S). From [Ya00], we have that R𝑅R is a Stanley-Reisner ring implies that ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)superscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S) is a square-free module. Thus, ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)superscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S) is uniquely determined by its prime ideals generated by variables. Therefore, we only need to consider primes generated by variables when showing R𝑅R satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}).

Assume R𝑅R is (j+1)𝑗1(j+1)-locally connected and dimR=ddimension𝑅𝑑\dim R=d. If j≥d−1𝑗𝑑1j\geq d-1, then 1≥d−j1𝑑𝑗1\geq d-j. All Stanley-Reisner rings are (S1)subscript𝑆1(S_{1}), thus this case is trivially true.

Now we suppose j<d−1𝑗𝑑1j<d-1. When d>j+1𝑑𝑗1d>j+1, Gj+1​(R)superscript𝐺𝑗1𝑅G^{j+1}(R) being connected implies ΔRsubscriptΔ𝑅\Delta_{R} is connected. Thus, for all localizations of R𝑅R such that dimR𝔭>j+1dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗1\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}>j+1 we have that ΔR𝔭subscriptΔsubscript𝑅𝔭\Delta_{R_{\mathfrak{p}}} is connected. Therefore, we have that 0​p​t​R𝔭≥20𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭20ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq 2, for all 𝔭∈Spec⁡R𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R with dimR𝔭≥2+jdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭2𝑗\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq 2+j. This combined with the fact that all Stanley-Reisner rings satisfy (S1)subscript𝑆1(S_{1}) gives that R𝑅R satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}).

Now suppose R𝑅R satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}). By Corollary 2.3 of [Har62], we have that R𝑅R is locally connected in codimension 1+j1𝑗1+j. Thus Gj+1​(R𝔭)superscript𝐺𝑗1subscript𝑅𝔭G^{j+1}(R_{\mathfrak{p}}) is connected for all 𝔭∈Spec⁡R𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R.

∎

5. Resolution of the Alexander Dual

Let us use notation from [FMS14] to introduce Alexander Duality. Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field and S=𝕂​[x1,…,xn]𝑆𝕂subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛S=\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]. Let m𝑚m be a monomial. Let 𝔭m=(xi:xi|m)\mathfrak{p}_{m}=(x_{i}:x_{i}|m).

A prime ideal 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} is an associated prime of a square free monomial ideal I𝐼I if 𝔭⊇I𝐼𝔭\mathfrak{p}\supseteq I and 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} is minimal among primes ideals that contain I𝐼I. The set of all associated primes of I𝐼I is written Ass⁡(I)Ass𝐼\operatorname{Ass}(I).

Definition 5.1.

Let I𝐼I be a squarefree monomial ideal. The Alexander dual of I𝐼I is

I∨=(m:𝔭m∈Ass(I)).I^{\vee}=(m:\mathfrak{p}_{m}\in\operatorname{Ass}(I)).

In [ER98], Eagon and Reiner proved that a Stanley-Reisner ring R/I𝑅𝐼R/I is Cohen-Macaulay if and only if I∨superscript𝐼I^{\vee} has linear resolution. In [Yan00], Yanagawa generalized their result to say a Stanley-Reisner ring R=S/I𝑅𝑆𝐼R=S/I satisfies (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) if and only if I∨superscript𝐼I^{\vee} has syzygy matrices with linear entries up to homological degree ℓ−1ℓ1\ell-1 [Yan00]. We further generalize these statements for equidimensional Stanley-Reisner rings satisfying (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}).

Definition 5.2.

Let R=S/I𝑅𝑆𝐼R=S/I be an equidimensional Stanley-Reisner ring. We say that I∨superscript𝐼I^{\vee} satisfies (Nc,ℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑐ℓ𝑗(N_{c,\ell}^{j}) if

[Torγ⁡(I∨,𝕂)]β=0​ for all ​γ<ℓ​ and for all ​c+j+γ<β≤n.subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptTor𝛾superscript𝐼𝕂𝛽0 for all 𝛾ℓ and for all 𝑐𝑗𝛾𝛽𝑛[\operatorname{Tor}_{\gamma}(I^{\vee},\mathbb{K})]_{\beta}=0\textrm{ for all }\gamma<\ell\textrm{ and for all }c+j+\gamma<\beta\leq n.
Theorem 5.3.

Let R=S/I𝑅𝑆𝐼R=S/I be a d𝑑d-dimensional, equidimensional Stanley-Reisner ring with codimension c𝑐c. Then the following are equivalent for ℓ≥2ℓ2\ell\geq 2:

  1. (i)

    R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}).

  2. (ii)

    I∨superscript𝐼I^{\vee} satisfies (Nc,ℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑐ℓ𝑗(N_{c,\ell}^{j}).

Proof.

By Corollary 2.22.22.2, R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) if and only if

dimExtSn−i⁡(R,S)≤i−ℓ​ for all ​i=0,…,d−j−1.formulae-sequencedimensionsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆𝑖ℓ for all 𝑖0…𝑑𝑗1\dim\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S)\leq i-\ell\textrm{ for all }i=0,...,d-j-1.

We rewrite for convenience:

dimExtSα⁡(R,S)≤n−α−ℓ​ for all ​c+j<α≤n.dimensionsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝛼𝑅𝑆𝑛𝛼ℓ for all 𝑐𝑗𝛼𝑛\dim\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{\alpha}(R,S)\leq n-\alpha-\ell\textrm{ for all }c+j<\alpha\leq n.

The above is true if and only if for any prime 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} with height h<α+ℓℎ𝛼ℓh<\alpha+\ell and support F𝐹F we have:

(ExtSα⁡(R,S))F=0​ for ​c+j<α≤n.subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝛼𝑅𝑆𝐹0 for 𝑐𝑗𝛼𝑛(\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{\alpha}(R,S))_{F}=0\textrm{ for }c+j<\alpha\leq n.

By Theorem 3.43.43.4 of [Ya00], this is true if and only if

[Torh−α⁡(I∨,𝕂)]Fc=0​ for ​c+j<α≤n.subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptTorℎ𝛼superscript𝐼𝕂superscript𝐹𝑐0 for 𝑐𝑗𝛼𝑛[\operatorname{Tor}_{h-\alpha}(I^{\vee},\mathbb{K})]_{F^{c}}=0\textrm{ for }c+j<\alpha\leq n.

By rewriting, we recover our definition of (Nc,ℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑐ℓ𝑗(N_{c,\ell}^{j}).

∎

Remark 5.4.

From this result, we have R𝑅R satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) if and only if all entries of the first syzygy matrix of R𝑅R have degree at most j+1𝑗1j+1. Furthermore, R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) if the sum of the highest degrees of the first ℓ−1ℓ1\ell-1 syzygy matrices is less than j+ℓ−1𝑗ℓ1j+\ell-1.

Corollary 5.5.

Let 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} be a pure, square-free monomial ideal of an n𝑛n-dimensional polynomial ring over a field.

(111) If 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} satisfies (Nc,2j)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑐2𝑗(N_{c,2}^{j}) and c≤n−1𝑐𝑛1c\leq n-1, then

reg⁡𝔞≤n−1−⌊n−2−jc⌋reg𝔞𝑛1𝑛2𝑗𝑐\operatorname{reg}\mathfrak{a}\leq n-1-\lfloor\frac{n-2-j}{c}\rfloor

(222) If 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} satisfies (Nc,3j)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑐3𝑗(N_{c,3}^{j}) and c≤n−2𝑐𝑛2c\leq n-2, then

reg⁡𝔞≤n−2−⌊n−3−jc⌋reg𝔞𝑛2𝑛3𝑗𝑐\operatorname{reg}\mathfrak{a}\leq n-2-\lfloor\frac{n-3-j}{c}\rfloor

Proof.

From Theorem 5.3 we get that S/𝔞∨𝑆superscript𝔞S/\mathfrak{a}^{\vee} satisfies (S2j)subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑗2(S^{j}_{2}), and cd⁡(S,𝔞∨)=reg⁡𝔞cd𝑆superscript𝔞reg𝔞\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a}^{\vee})=\operatorname{reg}\mathfrak{a}. Therefore, applying Theorem 3.43.43.4 we get the desired bounds. ∎

6. A generalization of Reisner’s criterion

Reisner’s criterion is a method for checking the Cohen-Macaulayness of a Stanley-Reisner ring by considering the reduced homology groups of the ring’s associated complex. The i𝑖ith reduced homology group of ΔΔ\Delta is H~i​(Δ;𝕂)subscript~𝐻𝑖Δ𝕂\tilde{H}_{i}(\Delta;\mathbb{K}). The following theorem is from [Rei76].

Theorem 6.1 (Reisner’s Criterion).

Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field and ΔΔ\Delta be a simplicial complex of dimension d−1𝑑1d-1. Then ΔΔ\Delta is Cohen-Macaulay over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} if and only if for every F∈Δ𝐹ΔF\in\Delta and for every i<dim(lkΔ⁡(F))𝑖dimensionsubscriptlkΔ𝐹i<\dim(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F)), H~i​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂0\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K})=0 holds true.

Terai has formulated an analogue of this theorem for Stanley-Reisner rings satisfying (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) (ℓ≥2ℓ2\ell\geq 2).

Theorem 6.2 ([Ter07] described after Theorem 1.41.41.4).

Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field and ΔΔ\Delta be a simplicial complex of dimension d−1𝑑1d-1. Then ΔΔ\Delta satisfies (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} if and only if for every F∈Δ𝐹ΔF\in\Delta (including F=∅𝐹F=\emptyset) with |F|≤d−i−2𝐹𝑑𝑖2|F|\leq d-i-2 and for every −1≤i≤ℓ−21𝑖ℓ2-1\leq i\leq\ell-2, H~i​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂0\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K})=0 holds true.

Now we present a lemma, which serves as an analogue to one direction of Reisner’s criterion for rings satisfying (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Following this Lemma, we prove a full analogue of Reisner’s criterion for equidimensional rings satisfying (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). For the rest of this section, R𝑅R shall be the Stanley-Reisner ring of ΔΔ\Delta and 𝔪𝔪\mathfrak{m} shall be the unique homogeneous maximal ideal of R𝑅R.

Lemma 6.3.

Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field and ΔΔ\Delta be a simplicial complex of dimension d−1𝑑1d-1. For a face F𝐹F let dFsubscript𝑑𝐹d_{F} denote the cardinality of the largest facet containing F𝐹F. Then ΔΔ\Delta satisfying (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) (ℓ≥2ℓ2\ell\geq 2) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} implies for every F∈Δ𝐹ΔF\in\Delta (including F=∅𝐹F=\emptyset) with |F|≤dF−i−j−2𝐹subscript𝑑𝐹𝑖𝑗2|F|\leq d_{F}-i-j-2 and for every −1≤i≤ℓ−21𝑖ℓ2-1\leq i\leq\ell-2, H~i​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂0\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K})=0.

Proof.

Consider H~i​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K}) with −1≤i≤ℓ−21𝑖ℓ2-1\leq i\leq\ell-2 and |F|≤dF−i−j−2𝐹subscript𝑑𝐹𝑖𝑗2|F|\leq d_{F}-i-j-2. Let us localize R𝑅R at a prime 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} generated by the variables contained in F𝐹F. Let dimR𝔭=d𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭subscript𝑑𝔭\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}=d_{\mathfrak{p}}. Then (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) condition implies H𝔭​R𝔭β​(R𝔭)=0superscriptsubscript𝐻𝔭subscript𝑅𝔭𝛽subscript𝑅𝔭0H_{\mathfrak{p}R_{\mathfrak{p}}}^{\beta}(R_{\mathfrak{p}})=0 for all β<min⁡(ℓ,d𝔭−j):=b𝔭𝛽ℓsubscript𝑑𝔭𝑗assignsubscript𝑏𝔭\beta<\min(\ell,d_{\mathfrak{p}}-j):=b_{\mathfrak{p}}. In particular, H~β−1​(lklk⁡F⁡(∅);𝕂)=H~β−1​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝛽1subscriptlklk𝐹𝕂subscript~𝐻𝛽1subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂0\tilde{H}_{\beta-1}(\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}(\emptyset);\mathbb{K})=\tilde{H}_{\beta-1}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K})=0 for all β<b𝔭𝛽subscript𝑏𝔭\beta<b_{\mathfrak{p}}. If we can show i+1<b𝔭𝑖1subscript𝑏𝔭i+1<b_{\mathfrak{p}}, then we will have H~i​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂0\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K})=0 as desired. We have i≤ℓ−2𝑖ℓ2i\leq\ell-2 which implies i+1<ℓ𝑖1ℓi+1<\ell. We also have |F|≤dF−j−i−2𝐹subscript𝑑𝐹𝑗𝑖2|F|\leq d_{F}-j-i-2, which implies that i<dF−j−1−|F|𝑖subscript𝑑𝐹𝑗1𝐹i<d_{F}-j-1-|F|. Thus, i+1​<dF−|​F|−j𝑖conditional1bralimit-fromsubscript𝑑𝐹𝐹𝑗i+1<d_{F}-|F|-j, and dF−|F|=d𝔭subscript𝑑𝐹𝐹subscript𝑑𝔭d_{F}-|F|=d_{\mathfrak{p}}. Thus, i+1<b𝔭𝑖1subscript𝑏𝔭i+1<b_{\mathfrak{p}}. ∎

Theorem 6.4.

Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field and ΔΔ\Delta be a pure simplicial complex of dimension d−1𝑑1d-1. Then ΔΔ\Delta satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} if and only if for every F∈Δ𝐹ΔF\in\Delta (including F=∅𝐹F=\emptyset) with |F|≤d−i−j−2𝐹𝑑𝑖𝑗2|F|\leq d-i-j-2 and for every −1≤i≤ℓ−21𝑖ℓ2-1\leq i\leq\ell-2, H~i​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂0\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K})=0 holds true.

Proof.

Suppose ΔΔ\Delta satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Then the result follows from lemma 6.36.36.3.

Suppose for every F∈Δ𝐹ΔF\in\Delta with |F|≤d−i−j−2𝐹𝑑𝑖𝑗2|F|\leq d-i-j-2 and for every −1≤i≤ℓ−21𝑖ℓ2-1\leq i\leq\ell-2, H~i​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂0\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K})=0.

Then let us consider H~α−|F|−1​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)subscript~𝐻𝛼𝐹1subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂\tilde{H}_{\alpha-|F|-1}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K}). Let us examine the case where α<b:=min⁡{ℓ,d−j}𝛼𝑏assignℓ𝑑𝑗\alpha<b:=\min\{\ell,d-j\}. We have |F|>d−i−j−2=d−α+|F|+1−j−2=d−α−1+|F|−j𝐹𝑑𝑖𝑗2𝑑𝛼𝐹1𝑗2𝑑𝛼1𝐹𝑗|F|>d-i-j-2=d-\alpha+|F|+1-j-2=d-\alpha-1+|F|-j if and only if α+1>d−j𝛼1𝑑𝑗\alpha+1>d-j which implies α≥d−j≥b𝛼𝑑𝑗𝑏\alpha\geq d-j\geq b. Thus, H~α−|F|−1​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝛼𝐹1subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂0\tilde{H}_{\alpha-|F|-1}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K})=0 for any F𝐹F so long as α<b𝛼𝑏\alpha<b. We also note that α<b𝛼𝑏\alpha<b implies α<ℓ𝛼ℓ\alpha<\ell which implies α−|F|−1≤ℓ−2𝛼𝐹1ℓ2\alpha-|F|-1\leq\ell-2. Thus, if we have α<b𝛼𝑏\alpha<b, we have H~α−|F|−1​(lkΔ⁡(F);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝛼𝐹1subscriptlkΔ𝐹𝕂0\tilde{H}_{\alpha-|F|-1}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F);\mathbb{K})=0 for all F𝐹F. Applying Hochster’s formula, we get that H𝔪i​(R)=0superscriptsubscript𝐻𝔪𝑖𝑅0H_{\mathfrak{m}}^{i}(R)=0 for all i<b𝑖𝑏i<b. Therefore, we have 0​p​t​R≥b0𝑝𝑡𝑅𝑏0ptR\geq b.

We must prove that for any localization R𝔭subscript𝑅𝔭R_{\mathfrak{p}} with dimension d𝔭subscript𝑑𝔭d_{\mathfrak{p}}, we have 0​p​t​R𝔭≥b𝔭:=min⁡{ℓ,d𝔭−j}0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭subscript𝑏𝔭assignℓsubscript𝑑𝔭𝑗0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq b_{\mathfrak{p}}:=\min\{\ell,d_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\}. From [Yan00], we have that R𝑅R is a Stanley-Reisner ring implies that ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)superscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S) is a square-free module. Thus, ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)superscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S) is uniquely determined by its primes generated by variables. Support of ExtSn−i⁡(R,S)superscriptsubscriptExt𝑆𝑛𝑖𝑅𝑆\operatorname{Ext}_{S}^{n-i}(R,S) determines if R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Therefore, we only need consider primes generated by variables when showing R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). To examine R𝔭subscript𝑅𝔭R_{\mathfrak{p}} we consider the simplicial complex lkΔ⁡FsubscriptlkΔ𝐹\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}F, where F𝐹F is generated by the variables which are not generators of R𝑅R (see Remark 1.41.41.4).

We then have H~i​(lklk⁡F⁡(F′);𝕂)=H~i​(lkΔ⁡(F∪F′);𝕂)subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlklk𝐹superscript𝐹′𝕂subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlkΔ𝐹superscript𝐹′𝕂\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}(F^{\prime});\mathbb{K})=\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F\cup F^{\prime});\mathbb{K}) which is 00 when |F∪F′|≤d−i−j−2𝐹superscript𝐹′𝑑𝑖𝑗2|F\cup F^{\prime}|\leq d-i-j-2 and when i≤ℓ−2𝑖ℓ2i\leq\ell-2. Thus, we have H~i​(lklk⁡F⁡(F′);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlklk𝐹superscript𝐹′𝕂0\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}(F^{\prime});\mathbb{K})=0 when |F|+|F′|≤d−i−j−2𝐹superscript𝐹′𝑑𝑖𝑗2|F|+|F^{\prime}|\leq d-i-j-2 and i≤ℓ−2𝑖ℓ2i\leq\ell-2, and thus H~i​(lklk⁡F⁡(F′);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlklk𝐹superscript𝐹′𝕂0\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}(F^{\prime});\mathbb{K})=0 when |F′|≤d−|F|−i−j−2superscript𝐹′𝑑𝐹𝑖𝑗2|F^{\prime}|\leq d-|F|-i-j-2. We have d−|F|≥d𝔭𝑑𝐹subscript𝑑𝔭d-|F|\geq d_{\mathfrak{p}}. Thus, H~i​(lklk⁡F⁡(F′);𝕂)=0subscript~𝐻𝑖subscriptlklk𝐹superscript𝐹′𝕂0\tilde{H}_{i}(\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}(F^{\prime});\mathbb{K})=0 when |F′|≤d𝔭−i−j−2superscript𝐹′subscript𝑑𝔭𝑖𝑗2|F^{\prime}|\leq d_{\mathfrak{p}}-i-j-2 and i≤ℓ−2𝑖ℓ2i\leq\ell-2. Thus, by the above argument, we have 0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{ℓ,d𝔭−j}0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓsubscript𝑑𝔭𝑗0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,d_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\}. Thus, we have R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). ∎

Corollary 6.5.

Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field and ΔΔ\Delta be a pure simplicial complex. Then the Stanley-Reisner ring of ΔΔ\Delta, R𝑅R, satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} if and only if for every face F∈Δ𝐹ΔF\in\Delta with dim(lkΔ⁡(F))≥1+jdimensionsubscriptlkΔ𝐹1𝑗\dim(\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F))\geq 1+j, lkΔ⁡(F)subscriptlkΔ𝐹\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}(F) is connected. Note (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}) is independent of the base field.

Proof.

Suppose ΔΔ\Delta satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}). Then for any prime ideal 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} with dimR𝔭≥2+jdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭2𝑗\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq 2+j we have 0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{2,dimR𝔭−j}=20𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭2dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗20ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{2,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\}=2. Thus, dimR𝔭~≥2+jdimensionsubscript𝑅~𝔭2𝑗\dim R_{\tilde{\mathfrak{p}}}\geq 2+j. Thus, Hm1​(R𝔭~)=0superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑚1subscript𝑅~𝔭0H_{m}^{1}(R_{\tilde{\mathfrak{p}}})=0. Thus, by Hochster’s formula, we have H~1−|F′|−1​(lklk⁡F⁡F′)=0subscript~𝐻1superscript𝐹′1subscriptlklk𝐹superscript𝐹′0\tilde{H}_{1-|F^{\prime}|-1}(\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}F^{\prime})=0 for all F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime}. In particular, H~0​(lklk⁡F⁡∅)=0subscript~𝐻0subscriptlklk𝐹0\tilde{H}_{0}(\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}\emptyset)=0, which implies lklk⁡F⁡∅=lkΔ⁡Fsubscriptlklk𝐹subscriptlkΔ𝐹\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}\emptyset=\operatorname{lk}_{\Delta}F is connected.

Now suppose dimlk⁡F≥1+jdimensionlk𝐹1𝑗\dim\operatorname{lk}F\geq 1+j implies lk⁡Flk𝐹\operatorname{lk}F is connected. Thus, we have H~0​(lklk⁡F⁡∅)=0subscript~𝐻0subscriptlklk𝐹0\tilde{H}_{0}(\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}\emptyset)=0. The link of F𝐹F has dimension at least 111. Thus, if we take a face of lk⁡Flk𝐹\operatorname{lk}F F′superscript𝐹′F^{\prime} such that |F′|=1superscript𝐹′1|F^{\prime}|=1, then lklk⁡F⁡F′subscriptlklk𝐹superscript𝐹′\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}F^{\prime} is not empty. Thus, H~−1​(lklk⁡F⁡F′)=0subscript~𝐻1subscriptlklk𝐹superscript𝐹′0\tilde{H}_{-1}(\operatorname{lk}_{\operatorname{lk}F}F^{\prime})=0 for all |F′|=1superscript𝐹′1|F^{\prime}|=1. Thus, we have 0​p​t​R𝔭≥20𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭20ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq 2. This argument holds for all primes generated by variables such that dimR𝔭≥2+jdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭2𝑗\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq 2+j. If we have a prime 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} such that dimR𝔭<2+jdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭2𝑗\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}<2+j, we still have 0​p​t​R𝔭≥10𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭10ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq 1, since R𝔭subscript𝑅𝔭R_{\mathfrak{p}} is a Stanley-Reisner ring. Therefore, R𝑅R satisfies (S2j)superscriptsubscript𝑆2𝑗(S_{2}^{j}). ∎

7. Monomial Ideals

In this section, we consider monomial ideals that are not necessarily squarefree. For convenience, we will establish a few conventions. When we consider the depth of a Stanley-Reisner ring, we shall be considering its depth with respect to the unique homogeneous maximal ideal. When we speak of the localized Stanley-Reisner ring of a link, we shall mean the Stanley-Reisner ring of the link localized at its unique homogeneous maximal ideal. Throughout this section, let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field.

One of the most powerful techniques for working with such ideals is polarization. We reproduce the definition of [MT09].

Definition 7.1.

Let I𝐼I be a monomial ideal in 𝕂​[x1,…,xn]𝕂subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]. Let the minimal generators of I𝐼I be u1,…,umsubscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑚u_{1},...,u_{m} where ui=∏j=1nxjai​jsubscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗u_{i}=\prod_{j=1}^{n}x_{j}^{a_{ij}}. For 1≤j≤n1𝑗𝑛1\leq j\leq n, let aj=max⁡{ai​j}subscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗a_{j}=\max\{a_{ij}\}, and let N=max⁡{aj}𝑁subscript𝑎𝑗N=\max\{a_{j}\}. Then let

Definition 7.2.

The polarization of a monomial u=x1a1​x2a2​…​xnan𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑎1superscriptsubscript𝑥2subscript𝑎2…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑎𝑛u=x_{1}^{a_{1}}x_{2}^{a_{2}}...x_{n}^{a_{n}} is

In [HTT05], Herzog, Takayama, and Terai proved that for a monomial ideal I𝐼I, S/I𝑆𝐼S/I being Cohen-Macaulay implies S/I𝑆𝐼S/\sqrt{I} is Cohen-Macaulay. In [PSFTY14], Pournaki et al. generalize this result to say S/I𝑆𝐼S/I satisfying (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) implies S/I𝑆𝐼S/\sqrt{I} satisfies (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}). We generalize this result further to hold for (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}).

Lemma 7.3.

Localization preserves (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}).

Proof.

Let R𝑅R satisfy (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Let S𝑆S be a multiplicatively closed set in R𝑅R. Let 𝔮𝔮\mathfrak{q} be a prime ideal of RSsubscript𝑅𝑆R_{S}. The ideal 𝔮𝔮\mathfrak{q} is the extension of a prime ideal 𝔭𝔭\mathfrak{p} in R𝑅R and so (RS)𝔮≅R𝔭subscriptsubscript𝑅𝑆𝔮subscript𝑅𝔭(R_{S})_{\mathfrak{q}}\cong R_{\mathfrak{p}}. 0​p​t​(RS)𝔮=0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{ℓ,dimR𝔭−j}=min⁡{ℓ,dim(RS)𝔮−j}.0𝑝𝑡subscriptsubscript𝑅𝑆𝔮0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗ℓdimensionsubscriptsubscript𝑅𝑆𝔮𝑗0pt(R_{S})_{\mathfrak{q}}=0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\}=\min\{\ell,\dim(R_{S})_{\mathfrak{q}}-j\}.

Therefore, RSsubscript𝑅𝑆R_{S} satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). ∎

In [MT09], Murai and Terai prove that polarization preserves (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}). We will generalize their argument in the following lemmas.

Theorem 7.6.

Let A=𝕂​[x1,⋯,xn]𝐴𝕂subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑛A=\mathbb{K}[x_{1},\cdots,x_{n}] be the polynomial ring in n𝑛n variables over a field 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}. Let I𝐼I be a monomial ideal of A𝐴A. Suppose that A/I𝐴𝐼A/I satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Then A/(I)A/\sqrt{(}I) satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}).

Proof.

Using the lemmas and theorem in this section, we follow the argument of Theorem 8.3 of Pournaki et al [PSFTY14].

Let T/J𝑇𝐽T/J be the polarization of A/I𝐴𝐼A/I, where T=𝕂​[x1,…,xn,Y]𝑇𝕂subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛𝑌T=\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n},Y] is the new polynomial ring over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} with Y as the set of new variables. By Theorem 7.57.57.5, T/J𝑇𝐽T/J satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Let W𝑊W be the multiplicatively closed subset 𝕂​[Y]\0\𝕂delimited-[]𝑌0\mathbb{K}[Y]\backslash 0 in T𝑇T and consider F=𝕂​(Y)𝐹𝕂𝑌F=\mathbb{K}(Y). Then the localization of T/J𝑇𝐽T/J at W is isomorphic to:

F[x1,…,xn]/(I)≅(𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))⊗𝕂F.F[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I)\cong(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))\otimes_{\mathbb{K}}F.

Since localization preserves generalized Serre’s condition, (𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))⊗𝕂F(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))\otimes_{\mathbb{K}}F satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Now to finish the proof, we will mirror the argument found in Section 2.1 of [BH98]. We wish to show (𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))⊗𝕂F(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))\otimes_{\mathbb{K}}F satisfying (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) implies (𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I)) satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Let us consider 𝔭∈Spec(𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I)). Since (𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))⊗𝕂F(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))\otimes_{\mathbb{K}}F is faithfully flat, there exists a 𝔮∈Spec(𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))⊗𝕂F\mathfrak{q}\in\operatorname{Spec}(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))\otimes_{\mathbb{K}}F such that 𝔭=(𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))∩𝔮\mathfrak{p}=(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))\cap\mathfrak{q} and 𝔮𝔮\mathfrak{q} is minimal over 𝔭((𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))⊗𝕂F)\mathfrak{p}((\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))\otimes_{\mathbb{K}}F). Therefore, 0​p​t​𝔭=0​p​t​𝔮0𝑝𝑡𝔭0𝑝𝑡𝔮0pt\mathfrak{p}=0pt\mathfrak{q}.

We will take M=R=(𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))𝔭M=R=(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))_{\mathfrak{p}}, N=S=((𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))⊗𝕂F)𝔮N=S=((\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))\otimes_{\mathbb{K}}F)_{\mathfrak{q}}. Since (𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))⊗𝕂F(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I))\otimes_{\mathbb{K}}F is flat over (𝕂[x1,…,xn]/(I))(\mathbb{K}[x_{1},...,x_{n}]/\sqrt{(}I)), N is flat over R. Thus, applying Theorem 1.2.16 and A.11 from [BH98] we get:

0​p​tS​M⊗RN=0​p​tR​M+0​p​tS​N/m​Nsubscripttensor-product𝑅0𝑝subscript𝑡𝑆𝑀𝑁0𝑝subscript𝑡𝑅𝑀0𝑝subscript𝑡𝑆𝑁𝑚𝑁0pt_{S}M\otimes_{R}N=0pt_{R}M+0pt_{S}N/mN
dimSM⊗RN=dimRM+dimSN/m​Nsubscriptdimension𝑆subscripttensor-product𝑅𝑀𝑁subscriptdimension𝑅𝑀subscriptdimension𝑆𝑁𝑚𝑁\dim_{S}M\otimes_{R}N=\dim_{R}M+\dim_{S}N/mN

Since 0​p​t​𝔭=0​p​t​𝔮0𝑝𝑡𝔭0𝑝𝑡𝔮0pt\mathfrak{p}=0pt\mathfrak{q}, we get dimR𝔭=dimS𝔮dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔮\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}=\dim S_{\mathfrak{q}}. Thus, 0​p​t​R𝔭=0​p​t​S𝔮≥min⁡{r,dimS𝔮−j}=min⁡{r,dimR𝔭−j}0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑆𝔮𝑟dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔮𝑗𝑟dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}=0ptS_{\mathfrak{q}}\geq\min\{r,\dim S_{\mathfrak{q}}-j\}=\min\{r,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\}.

∎

8. Skeletons

In this section, we examine the i𝑖i-skeletons of simplicial complexes. We begin with the definition.

Definition 8.1.

The simplicial complex Δ(i):={F∈Δ|dimF≤i}assignsuperscriptΔ𝑖conditional-set𝐹Δdimension𝐹𝑖\Delta^{(i)}:=\{F\in\Delta|\dim F\leq i\} is the i-skeleton of ΔΔ\Delta.

These i𝑖i-skeletons are smaller complexes that retain many important properties of the original complex. In particular, these complexes are a powerful tool for understanding depth. A complex whose Stanley-Reisner ring has depth b𝑏b has a Cohen-Macaulay b−1𝑏1b-1-skeleton.

Proposition 8.2 ([HTYZN11, Proposition 2.32.32.3]).

Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field and ΔΔ\Delta a simplicial complex. If ΔΔ\Delta satisfies (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}, then Δ(i)superscriptΔ𝑖\Delta^{(i)} also satisfies (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} for (2≤ℓ≤i+1)2ℓ𝑖1(2\leq\ell\leq i+1).

Theorem 8.3.

Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field and ΔΔ\Delta a simplicial complex with Stanley-Reisner ring R𝑅R. If ΔΔ\Delta is pure and R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}, then Δ(i)superscriptΔ𝑖\Delta^{(i)} is also pure and its Stanley-Reisner ring satisfies (Sℓmax⁡{0,j+i+1−d})superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ0𝑗𝑖1𝑑(S_{\ell}^{\max\{0,j+i+1-d\}}) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} for (2≤ℓ≤i+1)2ℓ𝑖1(2\leq\ell\leq i+1).

Proof.

Let us consider R𝑅R that satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Then 0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{ℓ,dimR𝔭−j}0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\} for all 𝔭∈Spec⁡R𝔭Spec𝑅\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R. As noted earlier, we may restrict our consideration to primes generated by variables. Let Δ𝔭subscriptΔ𝔭\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}} be the simplicial complex whose localized Stanley-Reisner ring is R𝔭subscript𝑅𝔭R_{\mathfrak{p}}. We note (Δ𝔭)(i−d+dimR𝔭)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}})} ≅(Δ(i))𝔭absentsubscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑖𝔭\cong(\Delta^{(i)})_{\mathfrak{p}} when d−dimR𝔭≤i𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑖d-\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}\leq i. We also note that if d−dimR𝔭>i𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑖d-\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}>i then (Δ(i))𝔭subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑖𝔭(\Delta^{(i)})_{\mathfrak{p}} has Stanley-Reisner ring 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} or 00, and thus is Cohen-Macaulay. It is known that the b𝑏b-skeleton of a simplicial complex is Cohen-Macaulay if and only if the depth of that complex is greater than or equal to b+1𝑏1b+1.

We consider two cases. First, i+j+1≤d𝑖𝑗1𝑑i+j+1\leq d. This is equivalent to |(Δ𝔭)(i−d+dimR𝔭)|≤dimR𝔭−jsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗|(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}})}|\leq\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j. If 0​p​t​R𝔭≥i−d+dimR𝔭+10𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭10ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}+1 then (Δ𝔭)(i−d+dimR𝔭)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}})} is Cohen-Macaulay. Otherwise, 0​p​t​R𝔭<|(Δ𝔭)(i−d+dimR𝔭)|≤dimR𝔭−j0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}<|(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}})}|\leq\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j. Thus, 0​p​t​R𝔭≥ℓ0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓ0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\ell. Thus, 0​p​t​(Δ𝔭)(i−d+dimR𝔭)≥ℓ0𝑝𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭ℓ0pt(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}})}\geq\ell. Combining these, we get:

0​p​t​(Δ𝔭)(i−d+dimR𝔭)≥min⁡{ℓ,|(Δ𝔭)(i−d+dimR𝔭)|}0𝑝𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭ℓsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭0pt(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}})}\geq\min\{\ell,|(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}})}|\}.

Therefore, the Stanley-Reisner ring of (Δ)isuperscriptΔ𝑖(\Delta)^{i} satisfies (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}).

Now consider the case i+j+1>d𝑖𝑗1𝑑i+j+1>d. Again if 0​p​t​R𝔭≥i−d+dimR𝔭+10𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭10ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}+1 then (Δ𝔭)(i−d+d​i​m​R𝔭)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑑𝑑𝑖𝑚subscript𝑅𝔭(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-d+dimR_{\mathfrak{p}})} is Cohen-Macaulay. Otherwise, 0​p​t​(Δ𝔭)(i−d+dimR𝔭)=0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{ℓ,dimR𝔭−j}=min⁡{ℓ,i+1−d+dimR𝔭−(i+j+1−d)}0𝑝𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗ℓ𝑖1𝑑dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑖𝑗1𝑑0pt(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}})}=0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\}=\min\{\ell,i+1-d+\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-(i+j+1-d)\}. Thus, we have the Stanley-Reisner ring of (Δ(i))𝔭subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑖𝔭(\Delta^{(i)})_{\mathfrak{p}} satisfies (Sℓi+j+1−d)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑖𝑗1𝑑(S_{\ell}^{i+j+1-d}). Combining these two cases gives the proof of the theorem.

∎

Theorem 8.4.

Let 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} be a field and ΔΔ\Delta a simplicial complex with Stanley-Reisner ring R𝑅R. If R𝑅R satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}, then the Stanley-Reisner ring of Δ(i)superscriptΔ𝑖\Delta^{(i)} satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}) over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} for (2≤ℓ≤i+1)2ℓ𝑖1(2\leq\ell\leq i+1).

Proof.

This proof will be similar to the previous proof.

Let us consider R𝑅R that satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}).

We consider two cases. First, i+1−n+dimS𝔭≤dimR𝔭−j𝑖1𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗i+1-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}}\leq\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j. This is equivalent to

|(Δ𝔭)(i−n+dimS𝔭)|≤dimR𝔭−jsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗|(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}})}|\leq\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j. If 0​p​t​R𝔭≥i−n+dimS𝔭+10𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭𝑖𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭10ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq i-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}}+1 then (Δ𝔭)(i−n+dimS𝔭)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}})} is Cohen-Macaulay. Otherwise, 0​p​t​R𝔭<|(Δ𝔭)(i−n+dimS𝔭)|≤dimR𝔭−j0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}<|(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}})}|\leq\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j. Thus, 0​p​t​R𝔭≥ℓ0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓ0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\ell. Thus, 0​p​t​(Δ𝔭)(i−n+dimS𝔭)≥ℓ0𝑝𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭ℓ0pt(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}})}\geq\ell. Combining these, we get

0​p​t​(Δ𝔭)(i−n+dimS𝔭)≥min⁡{ℓ,|(Δ𝔭)(i−n+dimS𝔭)|}0𝑝𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭ℓsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭0pt(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}})}\geq\min\{\ell,|(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}})}|\}.

Therefore, the Stanley-Reisner ring of (Δ)isuperscriptΔ𝑖(\Delta)^{i} satisfies (Sℓ)subscript𝑆ℓ(S_{\ell}).

Now consider the case i+1−n+dimS𝔭>dimR𝔭−j𝑖1𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗i+1-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}}>\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j. Again if 0​p​t​R𝔭≥i−n+dimS𝔭+10𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭𝑖𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭10ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq i-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}}+1 then (Δ𝔭)(i−n+d​i​m​S𝔭)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑛𝑑𝑖𝑚subscript𝑆𝔭(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-n+dimS_{\mathfrak{p}})} is Cohen-Macaulay. Otherwise, 0​p​t​(Δ𝔭)(i−n+dimS𝔭)=0​p​t​R𝔭≥min⁡{ℓ,dimR𝔭−j}=min⁡{ℓ,i+1−n+dimS𝔭−(i+j+1−n−dimR𝔭+dimS𝔭)}0𝑝𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝔭𝑖𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭0𝑝𝑡subscript𝑅𝔭ℓdimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑗ℓ𝑖1𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭𝑖𝑗1𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭0pt(\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}})^{(i-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}})}=0ptR_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq\min\{\ell,\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}-j\}=\min\{\ell,i+1-n+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}}-(i+j+1-n-\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}})\}. We note if i+j+1−n−dimR𝔭+dimS𝔭≥j𝑖𝑗1𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭𝑗i+j+1-n-\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}+\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq j then i+1−dimR𝔭≥(n−dimS𝔭)𝑖1dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭i+1-\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}\geq(n-\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}}). We note n−dimS𝔭𝑛dimensionsubscript𝑆𝔭n-\dim S_{\mathfrak{p}} is positive and thus we get i+1≥dimR𝔭𝑖1dimensionsubscript𝑅𝔭i+1\geq\dim R_{\mathfrak{p}}. In this case, we note we would merely be examining Δ𝔭subscriptΔ𝔭\Delta_{\mathfrak{p}}. Thus, we have the Stanley-Reisner ring of (Δ(i))𝔭subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑖𝔭(\Delta^{(i)})_{\mathfrak{p}} satisfies (Sℓj)superscriptsubscript𝑆ℓ𝑗(S_{\ell}^{j}). Combining these two cases gives the proof of the theorem.

∎
